comment: Professor Vande Ven is an erratic, clueless professor. He gives a definition assignment and claims you're plagiarizing because your answers look like everyone else. He doesn't respond to emails or if he does, it's rarely helpful. I had to go report him to the dean's office.

Professor Vande Ven was one of the worst professors I have had at KSU. I can say the worst professor in the nation. He is a really tough grader, and sometimes he doesn't know what he's talking about. Do not take his class forever unless you want to get crazy or wasting time. I regretted to take his course and wasted time.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Beware of pop quizzes--Tough grader

comment: Professor Vande Ven was one of the worse professors I have had at KSU. The assignments are vague and when you ask him any questions he basically tells you to figure it out. He doesn't show interest in helping students learn. He is a really tough grader. You are better off taking this class with someone else who actually helps and wants to teach.

Professor John Vande Ven is a man who knows his stuff, and grins at the fact that you don't. Between harsh emails and the 'do it yourself' attitude, you are alone in this class. The book is scarcely helpful and when it comes to assignments, you better know your stuff, otherwise you'll lose tons of points. Even with working code DO NOT TAKE HIM!
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Very vague with his requirements in assignments, his assignment requirements are not logical in design, simpler/more efficient solutions exist. He is a very tough grader as well, and has expected us to include code in one assignment BEFORE we studied the chapter that covered the code. Pass over this guy or buy the book and do it yourself.

When I asked him a question to clear something up, he said Youll have to figure it out yourself. I wasnt sure what I was missing because I never got good feedback. His lectures, by the way, were extremely boring.

He doesn't explain things in a way for students to learn on their own. "Look it up on Google" was the usual response I would get when needing help on assignments. Communication with students through email wasn't there at all, leaving you to do everything on your own. Assignments weren't explained well in detail. Acted like he didn't want to teach.

I really didn't want to give him this score. The instructions for the assignments he gives out are as  vague as his lectures. I know he wants us to learn on our own, but I feel as if I missed a class even though this is just the second java class in my program. I really want to enjoy this class, but I just can't with this professor.

I have taken Professor Vande Ven for CS 1302 and for database systems. He is one of the best professors I have ever had; however, he WILL NOT feed you the information. His philosophy is very much to learn by doing. He is intelligent and has a wealth of relevant experience. If you are willing to work and want to learn the material, he is great.

The course was online. He hardly ever communicated with the students and there were few assignments with vague feedback and no upfront expectations. The lectures are detailed and long, but with few labs it was hard to grasp anything.
Not worth your time! Take other database course for KSU catalog

Had him for 1302J my freshman year in SPSU. Hardly had any tests. Just a bunch of labs and one final project, which is a maze.   the maze project is a group project too. I managed to get A's on the labs but never finished the maze project. wound up with a B in the course even tho i never finished the project. Just do the labs and you'll be fine.

Really tough professor. You basically have to teach yourself because you most likely understand most of what he is saying. You can find most of the labs on the internet but there are a few you won't be able to find so you better find someone who knows how to code. Tests are hit or miss. No homework outside of class, mainly work on it during lab .

He tends to get off topic when lecturing but I like the "real world" examples he provides apart from going through the PowerPoint. Tests can be confusing because he's not super clear as to what will be on it or in what format but he curves. Final project wasn't bad. Never used the book (I never even bought one).

Really fun and interesting for a while, but he's very vague on test dates. He doesn't make it particularly easy to learn java and he assigns a couple of difficult labs and a final that is way beyond your experience if you started programming in college. Be ready for a ridiculous amount of googling if you take his class.

This professor is always taking about the possible career options in CS. I haven't taken this class to counsel me on career, I took the class so i can learn java. He knows whats he talking about but the students are clueless because he reads off ppt slides. Expect a lot of lab assignments and the FINAL PROJECT!!! (Hard as HELL!!!) . Beware!

Currently a freshman learning java. The class is long, but worth it. Tends to be repetitive but knows his stuff. There's opportunities for extra credit. Labs are relatively straightforward and makes programming fun. Challenging but in a good way. Though the lab assistants aren't very helpful,. collaboration is key!! definitely recommended! )

Vande Ven is not the worst professor. His class was relatively easy. The biggest problem is that he tends to teach way above the class level. He makes a lot of assumptions about what you know, and will do so over and over again. He likes to teach the material that he believes is important, even if it's not actually in the course material.

Use outside sources to verify what this professor says in lecture. He teaches from his long industry experience, and he sometimes gets things mixed up. His lectures often stray off topic and devolve into personal anecdotes. If this course is your introduction to programming with data structures, you are in for a tough time. Textbook use is minimal.

this man knows his stuff and the cs majors easily understand him... but on the other hand if you have no clue about programming you are not going to pass he cant communicate with people who know nothing about programming and are taking the class because it is required. plus if you get the book it wont help his code is nothing like the books

You will fly through the book in about a month and the rest of the semester are labs/teaching that will help you in future classes(mainly data structures). He does say that the best helper is Google when you have questions. I only went to class because he would randomly hand out the sign-in sheet if there were less than half of the class present.

Teaching style is unorthodox and he makes the class fast pace.  *If you do not ask questions he moves as if you know it*.  I recommend him to anyone with a passion for coding, you will learn a lot.  If you just want the degree there are easier professors. We finished the text book 25% into the semester.  After that, special topics and review.

The previous comments surprise me about Mr.Vande Ven. He does a review over the material for each test. Just study the power points and you will make A. If you don't understand the programming labs get help from the teacher assistant and you will get A. Most people who do not do well in his class is because they get lazy.... Help is there if needed

This is my second time taking his class and will be the second time dropping his class. He goes through the powerpoint but his response for labs is always "use Google" his assistants are useful, but he's not too involved. Very nice guy, down to earth, but I don't recommend him in you have no clue what you're doing before starting this class.
Pleasant demeanor is the sole virtue. Attentive to brilliant students only. Strays to unrelated topics during lecture.

This class eats the time. Assignments do not come from the book. The book is mildly useful, so buying other reference books is a good idea. If you do not understand chance are others in the class do not either. Ask questions otherwise he will fly through the material thinking everyone understands. He is a good teacher.

This professor doesn't really teach. He gives presentations using powerpoints, but his main response is "use Google". His labs are simple enough, as was the final project. He's not all that bad, but you have to teach yourself most of the material. Also, he occasionally gives out extra points and takes attendance, so be sure to go to class.
Nice guy, very helpful. Very responsive to email. Has respect for student questions and concerns. Also shares stories about real world experiences on the job. I highly recommend him.
Took his class online, challenging for me (I'm more of a networking guy, not so much into coding/programming), but not too difficult really.

Great teacher. His favorite language is C++ so he is good about comparing and contrasting C/C++ and Java. His tests are somewhat difficult if you don't truly understand programming. A lot of his tests were code snippets.IMO,spend more time programming than studying and you'll have no problems. Loves nerdy humor and is a very experienced programmer.

He definitely knows what he's talking about having worked in the field for so long.  I registered to take him again next semester because I feel like he gives a realistic portrayal of what programming is in the real world. He is a good teacher overall. But I will say that his tests are hard x.x

He gives out tough assignments, doesn't keep you up to date with your score, is hard to get a hold of, and tends to go on tangents. But tries to make it interesting, and if you show up to class, he grades you fairly. I had him at 8:30 am, and sometimes making it to class as a computer was tough, but doing my best, trying to communicate despite no reply, and showing up at every class I could gave me a miraculous 'A'.
Awesome teacher gets off topic sometimes but overral learned a lot. Tests are pretty hard but he's fair about grading.

This guy is a bank of knowledge, makes the class fun, he is dedicated, you do have to read and practice(its prgoramming)...and the labs are actual programming not sudocode grammer like other c++ profs, he weights the better of your test or lab..programming is about lab not lecture:)
Overall hes a great guy he didn't know a whole lot about the material and google was our main instructor.  Very easy I suggest taking him he's much better than Morrison!

Great guy, Great teacher, reasonable, logical, looks through student perspective and teaches you through that perspective. Hes goal is that his students would learn and understand programming , therefore if u know how to program at the end of the day he wont take anything against u(ull get an A)

Great teacher.Very knowledgeable about the subject. Has a tendency to get off topic. Creates almost impossible test. Students must learn the concept of the subject. Doesn't create test questions from the book. You will need to study but at the end of the class you will be able to apply the concepts for real world use.like investing in stock market
Gets off track, but always relates to what companies are looking in a job
He's very knowledgeable about the subject.  Sometimes he might start talking about stories from industry, but generally they were always relevant to what we were talking about.  Recommend him.

Terrible teaching ability, unclear, questions often left unanswered while he goes on tangents, unclear, made 3 appointments to see him in his office so far and he did not show up to all 3, tests are on information he fails to go over...
